Authors:
Girish Korekar, Ram K Sharma, Rahul Kumar, Prabodh Kumar
Bajpai, Harvinder Singh, Ravi B Srivastava, Paramvir S Ahuja, Tsering
Stobdan
Title:
Geographical Barrier Shape Population Genetic Structure of
Dioecious Pioneer Plant Species Hippophae rhamnoides L. in
Trans-Himalaya
Keywords:
Adaptation; Genetic Diversity; BARRIER; Morphometric;
Seabuckthorn; STRUCTURE
Abstract:
The present study aimed to investigate the role of
geographical barrier in shaping genetic and morphometric structure
within a natural population and to evaluate geographic distinctness of
Seabuckthorn (Hippophae rhamnoides L.) in trans-Himalaya. Seventeen
populations (N=187) from two valleys, which are geographically separated
by high mountains were collected. Genetic and morphometric diversity of
H. rhamnoides L. was moderate with significantly low (r2=0.1012) or no
altitudinal variation among the populations. Closely related populations
in the valleys were geographically restricted with significantly high
genetic differentiation. A significant isolation-by-distance pattern has
been observed. Model-based Bayesian clustering, principal component
analysis and neighbor-joining analysis highlighted the role of high
mountain Ladakh range (6500m amsl) as an important geographical barrier
for this species in the studied site. Two main gene pools, one in Leh
valley and other in Nubra valley have been observed. Moderate Neis gene
diversity (0.1559) was recorded with low gene flow (2.4215). A parallel
pattern of morphometric and genetic diversity was found. The Shannons
diversity index for 20 quantitative morphometric characters was 0.859,
which indicated high morphological diversity. Neis gene diversity showed
highly significant negative correlation with number of leaf/10cm2
(-0.936) and positive correlation with seed index (0.751). With
altitudinal gradient, leaf density decreased while thorn density
increases as a morphological adaptation to sustain in the harsh
environment.
